prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator will be set up in FDM mode in one of the basebands, covering the redshifted CO 1-0 line, with averaging of 8 to obtain a resolution of ~ 11 km/s, far smaller than the expected line width. The other three basebands will be observed in TDM mode, to search for any continuum emission from the GRB host galaxy.

For this GRB host galaxy, at z=0.089, the CO 1-0 line is the only one of the low-J CO transitions that are redshifted into an ALMA receiver band; we hence target this line. We have estimated the line full width at half maximum (FWHM) from the measured stellar mass and the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation; this gives a line FWHM of 105 km/s. The expected molecular gas mass is estimated from the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass as measured in galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG survey; Bothwell et al. 2014). Finally, we have used a metallicity-dependent CO-to-H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO = 5.4 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1 for this system) to estimate the CO line luminosity, and combine this with the expected line FWHM to obtain a peak CO 1-0 line flux density of 6.04 mJy. We aim to detect this expected line flux density at 5 sigma significance at a velocity resolution matched to the line FWHM, i.e. 105 km/s. This implies an RMS noise of 1.2 mJy per 105 km/s.

The correlator will be set up in FDM mode in one of the basebands, covering the redshifted CO 1-0 line, with averaging of 8 to obtain a resolution of ~ 13 km/s, far smaller than the expected line width. The other three basebands will be observed in TDM mode, to search for any continuum from the GRB host galaxy.

We request the most compact ALMA configuration so as to not resolve out the CO emission; this would yield an angular resolution of 3.90 arcsec at the redshifted CO 1-0 line frequency, corresponding to a spatial extent of ~ 17 kpc at the GRB host galaxy redshift of z=0.296.

For this GRB host galaxy, at z=0.296, the CO 1-0 line is the only low-J CO transition that is redshifted into one of the ALMA frequency bands; we hence target this line. We estimate the line full width at half maximum (FWHM) to be 128 km/s from the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation. The expected molecular gas mass is estimated from the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass in galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG sample; Bothwell et al. 2014). Finally, we use a metallicity-dependent CO-to-H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO = 3.8 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1 for this GRB host galaxy) to estimate the CO 1-0 line luminosity, and combine this with the line FWHM to obtain a peak CO 1-0 line flux density of 1.41 mJy. We aim to detect this expected line flux density at 5 sigma significance at a velocity resolution matched to the line FWHM, i.e. 128 km/s, and hence require an RMS noise of 0.27 mJy per 128 km/s channel.

The correlator will be set up in FDM mode in one of the basebands, covering the redshifted CO 2-1 line, with averaging of 8 to obtain a resolution of ~ 8 km/s, far smaller than the expected line width. The other three basebands will be observed in TDM mode, to search for any continuum from the GRB host galaxy.

For this GRB host galaxy, at z=0.584, the CO 2-1 line is the only low-J CO transition that is redshifted into one of the ALMA frequency bands; we hence target this line. We estimate the line full width at half maximum (FWHM) to be 122 km/s from the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation. The expected molecular gas mass is estimated from the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass in galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG sample; Bothwell et al. 2014). We then use a metallicity-dependent CO-to-H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO = 4.11 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1 for this GRB host galaxy) to estimate the expected CO 1-0 line luminosity. Finally, we conservatively assume that the CO rotational levels are not thermalized, and that the CO 2-1 line is a factor of 2.5 stronger than the CO 1-0 line, the ratio measured in the Milky Way (Fixsen et al. 1999). We combine this with the line FWHM to obtain a peak CO 2-1 line flux density of 1.1 mJy. We aim to detect this expected line flux density at 5 sigma significance at a velocity resolution matched to the line FWHM, i.e. 128 km/s. This implies an RMS noise of 0.22 mJy per 122 km/s channel.

The correlator will be set up in FDM mode in one of the basebands, covering the redshifted CO 3-2 line, with averaging of 8 to obtain a resolution of ~ 8.5 km/s, far smaller than the expected line width. The other three basebands will be observed in TDM mode, to search for any continuum from the GRB host galaxy.

For this GRB host galaxy, at z=1.496, both the CO 3-2 and 2-1 lines fall are redshifted into the ALMA frequency bands. The CO 3-2 line is expected to be stronger than the 2-1 line, by a factor of ~ 1.4 in the Milky Way (Fixsen et al. 1999); we hence choose to target this line. We estimate the line full width at half maximum (FWHM) to be 122 km/s from the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation. The expected molecular gas mass is estimated from the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass in galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG sample; Bothwell et al. 2014). We then use a metallicity-dependent CO-to-H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO = 5.7 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1 for this GRB host galaxy) to estimate the expected CO 1-0 line luminosity. Finally, we conservatively assume that the CO rotationa levels are not thermalized, and that the CO 3-2 line is a factor of 3.5 stronger than the CO 1-0 line, the ratio measured in the Milky Way (Fixsen et al. 1999). We combine this with the line FWHM to obtain a peak CO 3-2 line flux density of 0.78 mJy. We aim to detect this expected line flux density at 5 sigma significance at a velocity resolution matched to the line FWHM, i.e. 180 km/s. This implies an RMS noise of 0.155 mJy per 180 km/s channel.

The correlator will be set up in FDM mode in one of the basebands, covering the redshifted CO 3-2 line, with averaging of 8 to obtain a resolution of ~ 10.5 km/s, far smaller than the expected line width. The other three basebands will be observed in TDM mode, to search for any continuum from the GRB host galaxy.

For this GRB host galaxy, at z=2.086, both the CO 3-2 and 4-3 lines fall are redshifted into the ALMA frequency bands. The CO 3-2 line is expected to be stronger than the 4-3 line, by a factor of ~ 1.4 in the Milky Way (Fixsen et al. 1999); we hence choose to target this line. We estimate the line full width at half maximum (FWHM) to be 225 km/s from the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation. The expected molecular gas mass is estimated from the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass in galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG sample; Bothwell et al. 2014). We then use a metallicity-dependent CO-to-H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO = 5.8 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1 for this GRB host galaxy) to estimate the expected CO 1-0 line luminosity. Finally, we conservatively assume that the CO rotation levels are not thermalized, and that the CO 3-2 line is a factor of 3.5 stronger than the CO 1-0 line, the ratio measured in the Milky Way (Fixsen et al. 1999). We combine this with the line FWHM to estimate the peak CO 3-2 line flux density of 0.92 mJy. We aim to detect this expected line flux density at 5 sigma significance at a velocity resolution matched to the line FWHM, i.e. 225 km/s. This implies an RMS noise of 0.184 mJy per 225 km/s channel.

The correlator will be set up in FDM mode in one of the basebands, covering the redshifted CO 3-2 line, with averaging of 8 to obtain a resolution of ~ 11.7 km/s, far smaller than the expected line width. The other three basebands will be observed in TDM mode, to search for any continuum from the GRB host galaxy.

For this GRB host galaxy, at z=2.452, both the CO 3-2 and 4-3 lines fall are redshifted into the ALMA frequency bands. The CO 3-2 line is expected to be stronger than the 4-3 line, by a factor of ~ 1.4 in the Milky Way (Fixsen et al. 1999); we hence choose to target this line. We estimate the line full width at half maximum (FWHM) to be 225 km/s from the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation. The expected molecular gas mass is estimated from the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass in galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG sample; Bothwell et al. 2014). We then use a metallicity-dependent CO-to-H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO = 5.8 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1 for this GRB host galaxy) to estimate the expected CO 1-0 line luminosity. Finally, we conservatively assume that the CO rotation levels are not thermalized, and that the CO 3-2 line is a factor of 3.5 stronger than the CO 1-0 line, the ratio measured in the Milky Way (Fixsen et al. 1999). We combine this with the line FWHM to obtain a peak CO 3-2 line flux density of 0.87 mJy. We aim to detect this expected line flux density at 5 sigma significance at a velocity resolution matched to the line FWHM, i.e. 225 km/s. This implies an RMS noise of 0.174 mJy per 225 km/s channel.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Long-duration gamma ray bursts (GRBs) are believed to arise in the death of massive stars, and hence, to trace regions of high star formation. Despite nearly two decades of studies, the physical conditions that give rise to GRB formation are still not understood. We propose to use the ALMA Band-3 and Band-4 receivers to search for CO line emission from a sample of six high-metallicity GRB host galaxies, selected to be the best current targets for a detection of molecular line emission, and spanning a wide range of stellar masses, SFRs and redshifts. The observations will allow us to (1) estimate the molecular gas mass in a sample of GRB host galaxies out to z ~ 2.5, (2) determine the star formation efficiency in the GRB hosts by comparing their SFRs with the gas mass, and (3) test whether GRB host galaxies have short gas consumption timescales, as suggested by the three present GRBs with detections of CO emission. With the detections of CO emission in GRB host galaxies over a wide range of stellar masses, star formation rates and redshifts, this project will take the first steps towards understanding the gas conditions in galaxies that give rise to GRB formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: National Centre for Radio Astrophysics, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research
